titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Metropolitan Opportunity Unit, Office Files of Elizabeth McKeon
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Metropolitan Opportunity Unit, Office Files of Elizabeth McKeon FA1235

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-05-01 01:02:28 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Metropolitan Opportunity Unit, Office Files of Elizabeth McKeon

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files Elizabeth, "Liz", McKeon created when she worked at the Ford Foundation as the Foundation's Representative for Russia and then as Director for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries. When McKeon was Representative for Russia, she was based in the Foundation's Moscow Field Office until its closure. She then moved to direct the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries within the Metropolitan Opportunity unit (MOU) of the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program (EOA).

The collection is comprised of three series containing subject files, grant files, and meetings and trips files. Subject and grant files document the work McKeon performed when she was responsible for the Ford Foundation's programming for Russia and Eastern Europe and worked in the Moscow Office. The grant files show how McKeon continued managing the close out of the Russia grants after the Moscow Office closed and she moved to the EOA. Meetings and trips files span across McKeon's tenures as Russia Representative and Director for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries.

Files in the collection pertaining to the Ford Foundation's programming for Russia and Eastern Europe document the Foundation's interests in arts and culture, media and journalism, human rights, medicine, legal education, and people with disabilities. These materials also document the history of the Moscow Field Office from the Foundation's plans to open the office in the mid-1990s to the Foundation's decision to close the office in 2009. Records discuss some of the difficulties the Foundation and other foreign NGOs had working in Russia towards the end of the Moscow Office's history.

Files created by McKeon when she served as Director for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries document that initiative's focus on combatting urban poverty in the Global South through socially inclusive urban planning and economic development.

Common material formats found within the collection include memos, correspondence, notes, drafts, reports, articles, grant reports, grant modifications, grant actions records, meeting materials, travel itineraries and other travel related documents, and publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of three series.
Original order was maintained as much as possible.
The collection arrangement is as follows:
Series 1. Moscow Field Office subject files, 1994-2011
Series 2. Moscow Field Office grant files, 2001-2012

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in two accessions in 2020 and 2022 and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2020:031 and 2022:028.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Many of the documents in the collection are in Russian. The lack of Russian language knowledge on the part of the archivist who processed the collection has influenced some of the archival description decisions.

did.unittitle: Moscow Field Office subject files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files related to the Russia and Eastern Europe programming of the Ford Foundation's Moscow Field Office. These files were created and maintained by Elizabeth McKeon, the Foundation's last Representative for Russia before the Foundation closed the Moscow Office. The series also includes files created by McKeon's predecessors as Representative for Russia, Mary McAuley and Steven Solnick.

The files give insight into the Ford Foundation's activities and history in Russia and Eastern Europe as well as the history of broader international philanthropy in the region. Earlier records in the series document the Foundation's planning and opening of its Moscow Office and give an overview of the office's grants. Later materials in the series show how changes in Russia impacted the Ford Foundation and other international NGOs working in the country such as the Russian government's adoption of Decree 485 which took away the tax-exempt status of grants issued by foreign NGOs like the Ford Foundation.

The files document the Ford Foundation's program interests in economic development, arts and culture, and human rights in Russia. There is also a draft report McKeon created when she worked at the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) that she shared with the Ford Foundation before she started working there.

Moscow Field Office grant files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains grant files from the portfolio Elizabeth McKeon maintained when she worked as the Ford Foundation Representative for Russia and Eastern Europe in the Moscow Field Office. Most of the files contain narrative and financial grant reports. Correspondence, grant modifications, and grant action records can also be found in several files.

Grantees documented in the series worked in various areas such as human rights, arts and culture, media and journalism, legal education, medicine, and supporting people with disabilities. The dates on the reports show how McKeon managed the close-out of these grants after the Moscow Office closed.

Meetings and trips files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains meetings and trips files Elizabeth McKeon created and maintained when she worked as the Ford Foundation's Representative for Russia and Eastern Europe and Director for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries. The files contain itineraries and other travel documents that provide evidence of the travel McKeon made for these trips. There are also materials such as correspondence, agendas, notes, and reports present in the series which document the substance of the meetings and visits McKeon had. Users should note that several files in the series contain just travel documents.

For the most part, the files are arranged chronologically. The first few files document trips McKeon made as Representative for Russia and include materials related to grantee visits. Some files created from when McKeon later served as Director for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries show how she finished off activities related to the Foundation's Russia and Eastern Europe program after the Moscow Office closed.

Trip files related to McKeon's work for the Special Initiative on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries within the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program (EOA) Metropolitan Opportunity Unit (MOU) document McKeon participating in meetings and site visits related to urban planning and development throughout various countries. One file contains materials from the first convening of the Ford Foundation's Learning Group on Urban Poverty in Developing Countries in Jakarta, Indonesia.
